summary: The Kendall Mountain Run is a historic 12-mile high-altitude challenge in Silverton, Colorado, that tasks runners with a brutal 3,750-foot vertical ascent to a 13,066-foot summit. Dating back to a legendary 1908 bar bet, the course follows rugged Jeep roads before concluding with a technical high-altitude scramble and a breakneck descent back to town.
uniqueFeatures: Bar Bet Origins: The race commemorates a 1908 wager where a Silverton miner bet he could summit the peak and return in under 90 minutes, establishing it as one of the oldest mountain running traditions in the United States.

Vertical Intensity: Participants climb nearly 3,800 vertical feet in just 6 miles, starting at 9,318 feet and finishing the ascent with a precarious, technical scramble over loose scree and talus to reach the 13,066-foot summit marker.

The Mountain Duo Challenge: The race is a centerpiece of a premier trail weekend, where athletes can earn the 'Mountain Duo' title by completing a 50K ultramarathon on Saturday followed by the steep Kendall peak run on Sunday.

media.title: Race Directoring
media.summary: A column by pro runner Dakota Jones that provides an evergreen historical account of the Kendall Mountain Run's origins, from the apocryphal 1908 miner's bet to the modern-day course route.
media.contentSummary: Pro runner Dakota Jones reflects on the philosophy of race directing through his experience with the Telluride Mountain Run. He contrasts the historical, low-key origins of the Kendall Mountain Run with the modern complexities of land management bureaucracy and commercialization, ultimately arguing for a race model that prioritizes the mountains and community connection over self-aggrandizement and high-profile hype.

media.title: US Skyrunning Series Announced
media.summary: An editorial announcement profiling the Kendall Mountain Run's inclusion in the Skyrunning series, detailing its 13,066-foot summit and the 'Run Steep Get High' philosophy.
media.contentSummary: An in-depth editorial announcing the launch of the 2014 US Skyrunning Series. The article outlines the series' structure across three disciplines (Vertical, Sky, and Ultra) and features insights from series director Ian Sharman and several race directors. It provides historical context on Skyrunning's presence in the US dating back to the 1990s and profiles specific races including the Kendall Mountain Run, The Rut 50k, and the Cruel Jewel 56 Mile.

media.title: Featured Trail Town - Durango, Colorado
media.summary: A regional spotlight that profiles the Kendall Mountain Run as a bucket-list event for its lung-busting climb and historic Silverton atmosphere.
media.contentSummary: A comprehensive profile of Durango, Colorado, as a premier trail running destination. The article details the town's extensive 300-mile trail network, including highlights like Animas Mountain, Horse Gulch, and the Colorado Trail. It also provides an in-depth look at the local running community, essential gear shops, and the town's vibrant craft beer and coffee culture, while featuring several local elite athletes and community leaders.

media.title: Mini Hardrock: Silverton's Kendall Mountain Run
media.summary: This editorial explores the race's origins from a 1908 bar bet and its reputation as a 'mini Hardrock,' detailing the climb to the 13,066-foot summit.
media.contentSummary: This article profiles the history and 2017 results of Silverton's historic 12-mile Kendall Mountain Run, featuring the victories of Joe Gray and Kathryn Ross.
